newsitem.title: CHINA: China's development bank recalls 31.524 bln yuan.
newsitem.headline: China's development bank recalls 31.524 bln yuan.

text.p: China's State Development Bank recalled 31.524 billion yuan ($3.79 billion) worth of loans and interest in 1996, fulfilling 87 percent of its target for the year, the Financial News said on Thursday.
The ratio of recall reached 90 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, the newspaper quoted bank president Yao Zhenyan as saying.

Yao attributed the high ratio to the bank's cooperation with the five state-run commercial banks -- the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China, the Bank of China, the China Construction Bank and the Communications Bank of China.

The bank was formed as part of a move to create a separate policy bank and reduce the number of policy loans by state-run commercial banks. That was seen as a way to encourage commercial banks to lend funds on market-based decisions and reduce the role of central planning in the banking system.
Despite the reform, China's commercial banking system is often still called on to fund ailing state-owned enterprises that are unable to make repayments.
